reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars She knew in her heart that he was right, but what was missing? Those little clues....
reviews.reviewText: When I picked up this booklet it never occurred to me that I was at a fork in the road. My direction changed while my nose was buried in the early chapters. As I approached the middle sections, it was clear that there was no turning back. My heart was won, but my mother and my husband would never accept my new pathway, plus they would be deeply wounded in their dear hearts by my actions. But, what can one do when the star of love leads this way or that? And that was not the first danger! The first real fright came packaged with dark hair, blue eyes, a curious scar along the left cheekbone, and a sardonic smile...

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2007
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars You Can Do It!!!!
reviews.reviewText: I have read several "how to" guides on both writing fiction and more specifically, writing romantic fiction. The thing that really stands out with this book, is that Leslie Wainger believes YOU CAN DO IT! She really believes in you. If you read this and heed her advice, there is a good chance that you may just be able to publish a romance novel.Whereas a lot of the other books are constantly reminding a novice writer that there is a very slim chance that she will ever be able to publish anything, this book is reassuringly positive. Leslie Wainger never underplays the fact that writing is hard work and takes a lot of time, patience and both physical and emotional energy, but she continuously offers positive reinforement for the efforts of the beginning writer.This book illustrates an idea to get you started that I have never seen in a "how to" guide or even in the many writing workshops and classes that I have completed. I am so excited by some of the ideas and secrets that Ms. Wainger shares in her positive, upbeat manner, that I have ideas for many new books!I strongly recommend that if you are serious about writing romance, you do not overlook this valuable trove of information!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2013
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Very Helpful and Informative Book for New Romance Writers!
reviews.reviewText: For many years (okay decades), I had a story in my head that I wanted to write. Since the Internet came along, it's become so easy to write and publish your own book! This book helped me get started. I thought that I would get very little 'new' information out of it, but my husband encouraged me to get it, and boy was I ever wrong! This book gave me some tips on things I had not considered and even some new info that I never knew about. All I can say is that if you are a BRAND NEW romance writer, this IS the book for you! The only reason I haven't given it 5 stars is that I found it a bit...wordy. haha I think some of the info could have been condensed into a smaller, "just-the-facts" book. But still a wonderful reference book that I will keep on the shelf for many years to come.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2011
reviews.reviewText: When I started out with the idea of writing a book, I was excited with a story that I wanted to tell. Putting the story on paper to create my book was something I needed a lot of help with. I joined Harlequin's So You Think You Can Write event and the Writing a Romance Novel for Dummies by Leslie Wainger was suggested, so I ordered it. Boy am I glad I did. It has so many helpful suggestions. I have so many places marked and highlighted that the book glowes. This is a great book and I recommend it to anyone who is interested in writing.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very Helpful: Looks to Be Useful Long Term
reviews.reviewText: This is very helpful and informative guide for the novice romance writer. Everything you need to know is in her -- how to start writing, how to shape your novel, how to go about finding a publisher, and so on and so on. I think I will probably use it a lot as I struggle to bring my own romance novel (now begun!!) out of the ether and into reality.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Needs to be more specific
reviews.reviewText: This is basically a guide to writing a pot boiler of any kind. It is not for the experienced writer. The competent writer, even a college student level does not need to be told to use the active voice and not the passive.This needs more specific advice on how explicit the language you need to use in sex scenes, it needs more specific advice on what qualities your lead characters must possess.And so on...this is a highly formulaic genre and what we need are more keys and help on how to fit that genre.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Want to be a Romance Writer?
reviews.reviewText: If being a Romance Writer is one of your goals, this book is a good place to start. Delivery was prompt and the book is as described. Thank you!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2013
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another MUST HAVE book for your writing reference.
reviews.reviewText: I have checked this book out at the library several times, but was unable to complete it in the allotted check out time. Now I can take my time and study this volume and use it as a reference for my writing. The low price made my decision to add this book to my reference library.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic Resource for Aspiring Romance Writers
reviews.reviewText: Sometimes when you read a book, you get a sense of the author behind it. In this case, I have the sense that Leslie Wainger is not only a highly competent editor of romance fiction, but also a wonderful person who really wants her writers to succeed. Reading this book, I feel like I can do it! Ms. Wainger's advice is fantastic. The "for Dummies" format is easy to use. Sure, a bit of the advice about computers sounds dated, but so what? This isn't a computer handbook.
Fantastic book with a lot of advices. I love it and I'd really enjoyed also a translated version in italian. Perfect for new writer tips.

I have always loved writing stories but it got lost along the way. Then I discovered fanfiction (yes, and I am not ashamed of it) and thought this was a good way to worm myself back into a hobby that I though I had lost forever. Although I think I'm an OK enough writer for the internet platform I'm using, there's always things to learn and to improve and as we all know, practice makes perfect. I stumbled across this book through browsing and bought it without thinking twice.What a good idea! It's very helpful, very insightful - it touches plotting, character development, conflict approach, romance-related dynamics, outlining, and it does all that without raised fingers and preaching undertone. It's clearly written by someone who knows what she's talking about and who enjoys passing her knowledge on.If you'd like to tackle your own romance novel but are unsure about how to get it done... this book will be a great friend in need!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good first All Round Writing advise
reviews.reviewText: A good all round book covering most issues a beginning writer needs to know about and will find helpful. Good to understand with relevant examples. I didn't give 5 stars because in some sections I found the comments too general or lacking of specific examples.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 11, 2009
reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent advice from an experienced editor
reviews.reviewText: This is one of a few 'romance writing' books that I keep on my desk. Leslie Waigner has produced a comprehensive guide to writing romantic fiction, and as editor at US publisher Harlequin and speaker on the craft, this lady knows what she is talking about.This book happily coexists alongside Leigh Michaels' 'On Writing Romance' and Kate Walker's '12 Point Guide to Writing Romance'. I say this because Waigner's perspective is that of an editor, and while she examines the key elements of romance writing such as conflict, climax, and resolution, her style of writing is lighter with less in-depth examples of dos and don'ts. See Michaels or Walker for this.However, Waigner makes up for this in many ways. She includes really useful sections that the others just touch on, for example, setting up a space in your home for writing, doing the dreaded but necessary focus on your finances and accounts, what to look out for when you are negotiating a publishing deal, as well as technical stuff like US versus UK word-counting (news to me!), and reorganising your life in order to fit in a daily word output.The book is well structured, and I myself always learn something new. Highly recommended.
